node.title: Australia scrambles for new AdBlue supply chains as shortage threatens shutdown of nation's trucks
node.alt: Trucks crawl through a central Sydney street
node.description: With serious fears an additive in diesel fuel will run out in weeks following China's export ban on urea, the government is racing to find supplies from other countries.
node.content:
["Australia will soon receive a crucial supply of diesel exhaust fluid from Indonesia, as the federal government approaches Middle Eastern nations for help avoiding a crisis that could grind the transport sector to a halt.\u00a0", "Trade Minister Dan Tehan is urging businesses not to stockpile the anti-pollution additive AdBlue, with a global shortage linked to China's grip on the market.\u00a0\u00a0", "The transport sector is warning that unless new supply chains are established, diesel trucks across the nation could grind to a halt wreaking havoc on the logistics industry and the economy.\u00a0", "Mr Tehan has told the ABC there are now around seven weeks of supply left \u2014\u00a0more than the five weeks reported late last week \u2014\u00a0after negotiations with international trading partners.\u00a0", "\"I've spoken to my Indonesian counterpart and there is some supply in Indonesia that we should be able to access in the coming weeks,\" Mr Tehan told the ABC.", "\"There have been representations made to Saudi Arabia, to the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and also Japan.\"", "AdBlue is a fluid used to reduce pollution from diesel engines, made mostly of urea and water.", "A global shortage of urea has caused China, the greatest supplier of the ingredient, to cap its exports to protect its own supplies and control soaring domestic prices of AdBlue.", "About 80 per cent of Australia's urea stocks\u00a0come\u00a0from China.", "Mr Tehan said he was confident that enough supply could be guaranteed in coming weeks but urged companies not to stockpile AdBlue in the meantime.\u00a0", "\"There is clear supply there that we can bring to Australia and given we have seven weeks already in stock, we are very confident we will be able to get the urea that we need into the country,\" Mr Tehan said.\u00a0", "
Tehan: We need to firm up supply chains
", "National Road Transport Association chief executive Warren Clark said Australia wasn't the only nation hit by the AdBlue shortage.\u00a0", "\"A lot of the AdBlue, or the chemical that goes into making it, is imported from China,\" Mr Clark told the ABC.", "\"The supply of that chemical urea has dried up from China. And hence, there's now a massive shortage of AdBlue In this country.\"", "", "
Australia's AdBlue supplies mostly come from China.((Supplied: Trevor De Landgrafft))
", "Mr Tehan said the shortage showed the need for Australia to \"firm up supply chains ourselves\".", "\"The pandemic has demonstrated that some supply chains are fragile and as demand has picked up, China is obviously using the AdBlue that it has for its domestic market,\" Mr Tehan said.", "Mr Clark said there were a few reasons why the supply from China had been switched off.", "\"We've heard things like the cost of fertiliser in China has internally gone up dramatically, and a large portion of that is urea,\" he said.", "\"So what they've said is that they do not want to export any urea to try and keep the price of local fertiliser down.\""]
